tweet: @Vingaard2 @StackingSaunter If you want to use it, you can transfer from an old wallet to a Taproot wallet and Taproot address with an on chain transaction

name: Andreas
tweet: @CallMeJossy Yes Taproot is Segwit v1 addresses (upgrade from Segwit v0)

name: Andreas
tweet: The Taproot upgrade is a "soft fork" which means it is an optional feature. You don't have to use it or change anything in your use of Bitcoin because of it. But many wallets are likely to implement it for cheaper fees and better privacy

name: Andreas
tweet: Taproot will increase Bitcoin privacy by making complex scripts (e.g. Lightning channel closure) indistinguishable from simple payments. Schnorr Signatures optimize transaction signing and open the door for many other features and optimizations

name: Andreas
tweet: Today the Taproot feature set (Taproot, Tapscript, Schnorr Signatures) locked in on the Bitcoin mainnet. It will be activated for use on November 2021. Wallet and infrastructure implementations have 5 months to code and test their use of Taproot if they want to provide to clients

name: Andreas
tweet:

https://t.co/0Ny5rvvQr2

name: Andreas
tweet:
Taproot will be locked-in for a November activation in the next 36 hours. 

A big success for #Bitcoin, Taproot introduces a second signature algo (Schnorr) and significant privacy features.

Also a big success for the "Speedy Trial" activation method with < 8 weeks to lock-in.

tweet: @s_trida You misunderstand me, I love NFTs. Hate the name, love the token.

name: Andreas
tweet:
To clarify: 

I think NFTs are amazing. I wrote about them in my book before they were really cool and popular. I also failed to name them better, though I did explain them as "deeds". 

Good news: poorly named things can become HUGE if they have utility and NFTs have lots

name: Andreas
tweet:
So let's just go with "it's the cool kids' way of saying NIFTY". It doesn't mean anything. It's a token that has nifty applications and uses. 

Or "I don't remember why nifty's were named, but here's what I can do with them"

name: Andreas
tweet:
NFT stands for "Naming Failure: Total".

If someone asks you what it means you have to explain 1 thing. 

If you unwrap it as "Non-Fungible Token" you now have to explain 2 things: NFTs and FTs. 

You actually made negative explaining progress.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet:
@JallyWhiskey @RevPriest @Mario_Gibney @allenf32 I see what you mean

You're not debating the use of the word, but saying that a semantic argument is not useful in the case that others do not understand the actual words and are responding based on an incorrect definition - thereby derailing the debate and shifting to semantics

name: Andreas
tweet:
@JallyWhiskey @RevPriest @Mario_Gibney @allenf32 Because the words have meaning and the meaning can be found from studying the etymology and structure of the word. 

It's not an appeal to authority to understand the prefix "ex" and "in" as having universally understood meaning in Romance languages.

name: Andreas
tweet: @RevPriest @JallyWhiskey @Mario_Gibney You just defined "extrinsic value", since it is assigned and not intrinsic. If it is assigned by context, an observer, or a user - then by definition it is "extrinsic". The value comes from an external context (ex-trinsic), not inside (in-trinsic)

name: Andreas
tweet:
@JallyWhiskey @Mario_Gibney Yes. If words have no meaning, then using them in debate or argumentation is pointless. The word "intrinsic" means that the value is in the thing itself absent any context, or external purpose. 

Such value does not exist.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Yung__Sharky @Mario_Gibney That's not "intrinsic", that's utility value. The value is in the use not in the object intrinsically. 

A hammer and nails are useless to someone in the desert who needs a glass of water. That means the value is not intrinsic. The word "intrinsic" means something very specific

tweet:
@spidercars86 @AIkarenSF I would buy a new one if the tamper seals were broken, but just out of an abundance of caution and because it's not worth $100 to risk. 

That said, there has been no demonstrated firmware compromise AFAIK that would survive a reset and firmware update.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet:
@AIkarenSF There is no evidence of a single compromised hardware wallet, compromised through the distribution channel. 

Maybe some people got pre-initialized wallets and were not aware enough to not use the included seed. But the wallet was not compromised, it could be wiped and reused

name: Andreas
tweet: @AIkarenSF The hardware is not important. The important part is the mnemonic phrase (seed) and its backup on a durable medium. You can replace hardware easily with any one of hundreds of implementations of the same standard.

name: Andreas
tweet: In our industry, almost everything is in English. I've spent years trying to build up content in a dozen languages (at great expense). My biggest barrier has been Youtube and Google. You'd think they'd want to help creators reach a global audience in 30+ languages. You'd be wrong

name: Andreas
tweet: This is how Google treats their video creators on Youtube and their developer partners for the APIs. Every few weeks or months I give it another go, only to get stuck in a Kafkaesque nightmare of keyword-driven bots with no possibility of speaking to a human.

name: Andreas
tweet: Then Google turned off community subtitle contributions and my thriving community of volunteers was gone. I could "move" the subtitling effort to another platform, but that requires use of the API. I started building that part too, then they turned off my quota.

name: Andreas
tweet: This same app automatically populated playlists so that viewers could find videos subtitled in their language, another obvious feature that Youtube is missing and that was easy to implement. That function is also not updating any more.

name: Andreas
tweet: As the channel got bigger (600+ videos, 1000+ subtitle files) it was not possible to operate it on the minimal standard API quota, so I asked for an increase. During the last audit in October 2020 they set it to zero, breaking the app completely. They have not responded yet

name: Andreas
tweet: This was the third time they had requested "addiitonal information" or audited the API use, even though it was relatively low quota. Each time, a series of low-level agents would punt for weeks on the basis of keywords.

name: Andreas
tweet:
I created a prototype that allowed people to search through the captions of my Youtube channel videos for text in 31 languages and jump directly to that moment in that video. 

Google "audited" my API quota automatically and shut it down. They've been unresponsive since October

name: Andreas
tweet: @pritchettdavid @starkness @michael_saylor It's not a sudden or discontinuous transition into a new model. It's a very gradual shift of incentives over 100+ years. The system dynamically adapts and reaches equilibrium every 10 minutes with very very slow changes in incentives over time

name: Andreas
tweet: Consider it debunked.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Several other incorrect statements are also made in that and other articles about RBF and Segwit. Here's the truth: this is a normal function of any PoW blockchain. A re-org with two different versions of a transaction can occur in every other PoW chain. 

23/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Someone article quoted the lie "it could've been $22 million". Well, no, it couldn't. If you accept a $22m payment on bitcoin, I would assume you understand how Bitcoin has worked since 2008, exactly as specified in the paper. You don't "deliver" on that payment after 1 conf

22/

name: Andreas
tweet:
In fact, we do not know that the recipient of that payment lost money. They may have been waiting for 2 confirmations and not delivered the other part of the value.  So in that case, they lost nothing - they consider this "unpaid" because it didn't get 2+ confirmations

21/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Many credit card vendors don't take a signature for amounts under $25 for the same reason: while it can be disputed without a signature, it's not worth the extra time and delay to get one for such an amount. Same risk model here.

20/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Now, for $22 many would accept 1 confirmation. Worst case, you're out $22 of something you gave in return that was delivered instantly and irreversibly. Not a big deal.

19/

name: Andreas
tweet:
During this most recent re-org, a transaction of $22 was in both competing blocks as two competing transactions. We don't know why. We don't know who. But there's nothing "impossible" about this. It is part of the protocol

18/

name: Andreas
tweet:
It also depends on the risk of the buyer going away. I'd sell a house on 0-conf, *because I know where they live!*. They can't run away with it. Some things are more dangerous: I'd wait 6 confs to exchange for cryptocurrency, because once I give it I can't get it back.

17/

name: Andreas
tweet:
So when do you consider a transaction finalized and when is it safe to give your customer the TV or the fiat or whatever value you are exchanging? It depends on the amount!

I waited 3 confirmations after selling my car for $11,000 USD (IIRC). Was enough for me. 

16/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Here's page 8. As you can see the chance of a block getting discarded from a reorg declines /exponentially/ as more blocks are added to the chain. Finality is based on probability. 

15/ https://t.co/RyBQ5tk0S0

name: Andreas
tweet:
This is described in the Satoshi whitepaper on page 8. In fact, it's the only math equation in the paper and it describes the declining probability of a re-org, showing why "6 confirmations", though arbitrarily chosen is a good basis to consider a transaction finalized

14/

name: Andreas
tweet:
From the perspective of the recipient, they thought they were "paid" after 1 block, then they... weren't. This is why "confirmations" provide /probabilistic/ immutability. The chance of a reorg drops with each subsequent confirmation

13/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Because the original transaction is gone (discarded block), the new transaction (winning block) is the only "real" transaction. The blockchain has prevented a double spend by discarding one and only recording the other. 

12/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Very rarely, the sender will sneak a *different* transaction in the competing/winning block. Let's say this is a payment for a lesser amount (more change back), or to a different address.

11/

name: Andreas
tweet:
But from the perspective of the recipient of a payment, they may see a transaction that appears to have 1 confirmation (it is in a block), then disappears when that block is discarded. 

10/

name: Andreas
tweet:
During a re-organization, there is a chance for someone to attempt a "double spend". This is not a double spend from the perspective of the blockchain as a whole. Only one spend survives, therefore no double spends happen. That's the whole point of PoW consensus. 

9/

name: Andreas
tweet:
What happens to any transactions in the discarded block? If they are also in the winning block then all is well. If they are not in the winning block, each node puts them back into its mempool as "unconfirmed" and they wait for another opportunity

8/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Again, all of this is normal. A 1-block reorganization happens every couple of weeks on average as a consequence of decentralized PoW. 

A 2-block reorganization happens less often, maybe a few times a year

A 3-block reorg is extremely rare. I don't think we've ever seen one

7/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Of the two originally competing blocks, one is now a parent and the other is the last descendant of a shorter chain. The chain with the greatest cumulative difficulty is selected by all. This "orphans" any descendants from the other chain because it is discarded. 

6/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Eventually, within an average of 10 minutes another block is mined. This new block has as its parent *one* of the two competing blocks. Which one? Whichever one the miner saw first and assumed to be the winner. 

The new block extends the chain, resolving the issue. 

5/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Only one can ever succeed in the long run. It is possible that different nodes and miners see one or the other block first and assume it is the winner. This is also normal in a decentralized consensus algorithm

4/

name: Andreas
tweet:
Two blocks were mined almost simultaneously, competing for the same height, meaning that they had the same parent block and were trying to extend the chain of the same block

3/

name: Andreas
tweet:
There was a chain re-organization in the Bitcoin blockchain. This is a common occurrence that is part of Bitcoin's normal operation. It is a result of decentralized consensus under Proof-of-Work. All PoW chains do this. 

2/

"A double-spend broke Bitcoin" FUD that was circulated by an irresponsible publication.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Guruxz1 Not a single-key paper wallet, those are obsolete and dangerous for newbies. Use a mnemonic paper backup instead

Paper wallets are just key storage mechanisms. You still need to load that key and sign somewhere. That somewhere is a hardware wallet. It's backup is a mnemonic

name: Andreas
tweet:
@DrDooba @mike_maloney @michael_saylor @pierre_rochard @adam3us There is a huge difference between:

a) Fixed Bugs
b) Unknown (Unfixed) Bugs
b) Exploitable unknown bugs
c) Unrecoverable Exploitable Unknown Bugs

If you stop at (a), you miss the fact that software is *evolving*. It's the entire system that resists corruption, not just one part

tweet: @JoelyBalazs ETH pre-sale was not BIP39. They used their own standard.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@BrianMales A 12 word seed is plenty secure. It offers 128 bits of security, which is not brute-forceable. Of course, 24 words offer 256 bits of security and that's not "double the security" it is 2^128 times more security.

Balance against the risk of moving and cost of transaction fees

name: Andreas
tweet: @JoelyBalazs Ooops. I guess I was just misremembering

name: Andreas
tweet: @JoelyBalazs I was avoiding actual BIP39 words.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@JoelyBalazs The dictionary is part of the standard and contains 2048 specific English words in a specific order. The standard will not change and the wordlist is public and easily found:

https://t.co/bCulZpYL16

name: Andreas
tweet: @JoelyBalazs The keys are produced from the actual words, space-separated and concatenated. A different dictionary or change in the words will produce a different set of keys. So you can't do that.

name: Andreas
tweet: @WieLKiWaFeL1989 That initial silence indicates an auto-dialer. It dials hundreds of numbers and if someone picks up and speaks it connects them to an "operator" with a script to start the scam. That indicates a degree of investment and sophistication in this operation.

name: Andreas
tweet:
If I received an email like this, I would ignore it. As scary as it is, it is a bluff. Still, it's a despicable tactic and very scary to receive. 

You can report this to your local FBI office - it is cyber-extortion and interstate fraud (at least). 

3/

name: Andreas
tweet:
The identical email has been sent to several people, which indicates it is a mass-bluff, likely being sent to everyone on the list whose shipping address was compromised. I haven't received one yet to verify the details. 

2/

name: Andreas
tweet: @theinstagibbs @omgbtc The only coins that exist in ETH2 today are those that were "transferred" from ETH1 via  the staking contract. So the importation happened already (in part) as an opt-in migration. In the next phase it happens for all remaining state in ETH1.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@theinstagibbs @omgbtc Yes

name: Andreas
tweet:
Mnemonic phrase backups part 3:

The two most important principles in security:

Keep It Simple Stupid (KISS)

Don't Roll Your Own Crypto (DRYOC)

The question "how about if I... <complex DIY solutions>" is answered with "No, keep it simple"

If you are worried about storing a mnemonic (seed) securely:

DO NOT split it
DO NOT "encrypt", "encode", "mix", "obfuscate" it. You will lose money. 

DO use the optional passphrase feature with 4-8  lower-case word passphrase. Backup separately.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Newbie PSA:

Do NOT use paper wallets. They are obsolete key storage technology and dangerous for newbies. 

Use a BIP39 mnemonic phrase instead, back it up on paper or better on a durable medium like steel.

name: Andreas
tweet:
NEVER store a mnemonic phrase online (not even encrypted)

NEVER type a mnemonic phrase onto any online device

ONLY enter the mnemonic phrase directly onto a hardware wallet

ONLY record the mnemonic phrase onto durable physical medium such as steel

name: Andreas
tweet:
It's especially maddenning for those of us who get the tragic and heartbreaking messages from all the people who lose money, fall victims to scams, get hacked etc. 

That advice you just offered? I just heard from someone a few weeks ago who lost everything because of that...

name: Andreas
tweet:
Infosec in cryptocurrencies is next-level difficult because the motivation for attack is built in to the system. Every system is a honeypot, even if it is a small honeypot. So every attacker has a direct and obvious payoff. 

Yet our industry is inundated by amateur "DIY" infosec

name: Andreas
tweet: Meanwhile, those who have decades of experience in infosec, both theoretical and applied, tend to be quite circumspect and measured. That's because they've seen it all and know how vast the space is and how fast it moves.

name: Andreas
tweet: Information security is a field that creates a *very* strong Dunning-Kruger effect. Those who know a little are utterly unaware of how much there is they don't know. So their confidence is at a zenith when it should not be.

name: Andreas
tweet:
I don't know why it bothers me so much, but I get worked up when amateurs decide to give information security advice, despite having no expertise.

It's the equivalent of dismissing the advice of your oncologist because your massage therapist suggested peppermint oil.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet:
@Open_Media So for anyone else reading this:

Do not follow this advice. It is not good. It violates good security practices and increases your risk.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Open_Media I am not defending Ledger and have no affiliation. I am just as incensed about how badly they mishandled this as anyone else. 

But giving bad advice that increases risk is not ok and I will call you out. My goal is to help people reduce risk, not stick it to Ledger.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Open_Media No, an encrypted storage solution can be used to store the key material, but the problem simply shifts to:
a) How do you open/write/read that
b) How do you sign transactions

Both of which are not secure to do in online software/OS, so you're back to needing a hardware wallet.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet:
@Open_Media This is the worst advice. 

1) It won't address the past breach risks
2) It fixes the wrong problem (the Ledger HW is fine)
3) It substitutes a hardware wallet for a less secure software wallet

Information security is not a place to give amateur advice, sorry.

name: Andreas
tweet: @bitcoin_dna @jimbocoin @COLDCARDwallet It computes the conversion to words and adds a checksum. It has a secure element and can be wiped leaving no trace behind. It can be operated off a battery.

name: Andreas
tweet: @jimbocoin @COLDCARDwallet The entropy to words does not require "code". It's simple arithmetic to convert from base-6 (dice) to base-2048 (words)

name: Andreas
tweet: @pcaversaccio Out of curiosity why would you use Shamir instead of an equivalent-scheme Multisig with multiple seeds.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Walodja1987 @mikeinspace For $230 you won't find many who are willing to spend the time. If your scheme is only good enough for that kind of amount, it's not very useful. 

Put 1 BTC on it and make a bounty. I'll be happy to retweet it for you.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@pcaversaccio A passphrase is preferable for most use cases. Shamir makes backup strategy more complex, so I would only do that for very large amounts. 

Even then I would use the Shamir SLIP39 standard so that it can be recoverable without special software or knowledge.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Walodja1987 @mikeinspace There's a reason why "Don't Roll Your Own Crypto" is the most important rule in cryptography. 

Caeser's Cipher on known-dictionary is weak.

If you don't believe me, put 1 BTC in a seed you encrypt with it and publish it.

I would publish a passphrase-protected seed with 1 BTC.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Walodja1987 @mikeinspace Pick the reason:
- Non-standard cryptography technique
- Don't Roll Your Own Crypto
- BIP39 has a standards-based second factor, the one I described
- You will forget how to undo this, or forget the key
- Your heirs will never figure it out if something happens to you

name: Andreas
tweet:
The top three rules of self-custody:

- Backup your mnemonic words, in order, 1+ copies, on a durable medium, in a safe location(s).
- NEVER enter those words online or on a device that isn't the hardware wallet.
- If you use an optional passphrase, back that up too, separately

name: Andreas
tweet:
I've been saying this for years. Bitcoin is a poison pill. Regulated institutions can't swallow it. By trying to regulate it, they end up making it less useful for those who use regulated institutions.

I said it again in a video last week:
https://t.co/2OO7ZrTaOt

name: Andreas
tweet: By regulating the main thing they can regulate, which is regulated institutions - they are inadvertently making those less appealing to use and pushing more and more people to decentralized alternatives and self-custody.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Or you can leave it on the exchange and have to explain yourself anytime you want to make a payment over $3000 USD

This year it will be $3k. Next year they will lower it even as it's eroded by inflation. Eventually all transaction will need reporting and control...

name: Andreas
tweet:
This will encourage users to withdraw immediately upon exchanging and often, as any money they let accumulate in a hosted wallet because less liquid and more bureaucratically bound. 

Not your keys, not your coins, your barriers to use.

Your keys, your coins, not your red tape.

name: Andreas
tweet: As I said, this hurts exchanges and hosted wallets because they have to do more compliance work and make users jump through more hoops. It makes their "product" look less functional than a wallet you control... because it is less functional.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Bottom line on the FinCEN rules (as I predicted): If you try to make payments from a regulated exchange they will require additional verification and will report your transactions to the government. 

If you use your own wallet... they can't and won't control or report on you.

tweet:
@mcuban @gladstein Here's another interesting insight on that point, that I heard from someone in Venezuela. 

When converting USD cash (e.g $20) to bolivars, they get the "change" in bolivars, losing value. But with Bitcoin they can exchange only a fraction & keep the change in a stable currency.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@mcuban @gladstein But Mark brings up an interesting point that I have discovered by using Bitcoin as my savings and earning it for my labor. 

When the value declines, my savings lose value but I get paid more BTC per hour. When it rises, I get less BTC per hour but my savings rise: self-balancing

name: Andreas
tweet: @Mario_Gibney Basically, the 21M cap is produced by a stepped decrease in issuance that occurs every 210,000 blocks or approximately every 4 years, resulting in 0 new issuance after the year 2140. At that point 20,999,999.999 bitcoin have been issued. For the last 4 years, only 1 sat per block

tweet:
@simonb03jan2009 Not really. There are too many deployed instances that can't be easily modified (such as embedded devices). So 100% consensus on changes is not possible - some nodes would still run the old consensus rules, which would still be "Bitcoin"

name: Andreas
tweet: @simonb03jan2009 It cannot be increased - 21m is an essential characteristic of what we call "Bitcoin". Any attempt to increase issuance simply creates a worthless alternative coin, which I will call "InfationCoin".

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet:
@evolvewithrogan @Ledger @Trezor No, there's no better alternative to a hardware wallet.

name: Andreas
tweet: @evolvewithrogan @Ledger @Trezor Again, as I've said many times. You do not "trust this company with your crypto". You trust yourself with managing your mnemonic and the device. The Ledger hardware continues to be secure and there's no reason to worry about using it.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Ledger @Trezor To be clear, this new phishing attack seems to originate from the same database that was stolen from @Ledger. The same (fake) name and number appears for me.  

It seems to be unrelated to @Trezor, other than the attackers using that name in their new phishing campaign.

name: Andreas
tweet: @digibbut @softlinkie @Ledger @Trezor A whole bunch of people will freak out and try and do something much riskier than a hardware wallet as an overreaction, leading to even more losses. I'm trying to prevent that overreaction that is based on poor threat analysis.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@digibbut @softlinkie @Ledger @Trezor Just to be clear, there is no indication that Trezor had customer database hacked. This appears to be the Ledger database with a different phishing message. 

Also I am not brushing it off. I'm providing non-hysterical threat analysis for free.

name: Andreas
tweet: @softlinkie @digibbut @Ledger @Trezor There was no Trezor leak, as far as I can tell. This is the same Ledger database, they're just trying to go after those who might also have a Trezor or didn't fall for the previous message. Who knows...

name: Andreas
tweet:
@digibbut @softlinkie @Ledger @Trezor Welcome to the Internet. It seems you have just discovered that websites get hacked. Are you new here?

name: Andreas
tweet: @softlinkie @digibbut @Ledger @Trezor Yes a harware wallet is superior in every way to a paper wallet.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@bitcoinisus My work is independent, above all else. I have never and will never endorse a product. I'm giving my informed professional opinion. 

This has nothing to do with Ledger or any other company. This is basic risk management and threat analysis.

name: Andreas
tweet:
The fact that you own crypto is not a huge secret. Unless you've been practicing great opsec, every social media company and anyone who buys their data can target you with phishing attacks. They'll take the ad money. 

Your security does not depend on you remaining obscure.

name: Andreas
tweet:
One is a centralized resource that is almost impossible to keep secure. 

The other is a decentralized device that is almost impossible to attack. 

Don't throw out a good technology because of an unrelated attack.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Don't overreact to the phishing scams that target hardware wallet buyers

Hardware wallets are some of the best mechanisms we have to store crypto. 

Compromising a website database is not at all the same as compromising the security of the hardware wallet.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet:
@softlinkie @DazzlingIf @Ledger @Trezor There's nothing they can do to "fix it". The data is out there and can be used to contact the buyers of devices. 

The way to fix this problem is to educate potential victims.

name: Andreas
tweet:
There are only two ways you can make a global digital economy:

- Systems that follow the rules and ask for permission

- Permissionless systems that don't ask

They will say no to the first, or impose unworkable control & surveillance. 

Choose the second.

name: Andreas
tweet: @elstreetphoto Multiply that by 194 jurisdictions to see why regulated entities cannot provide economic inclusion or opportunity. They will have to compomise to the lowest common denominator of 194 legal systems, all of which will require surveillance access in return for permission.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Stop trying to triangulate, moderate, compromise, cede, adopt, polish, and gentrify this technology. They will never stop demanding more control. There is no "middle ground" between authoritarians and free systems.

Don't be fooled - they honeymoon is over. It's gonna get rough

name: Andreas
tweet:
"Unregulated" is the competitive differentiation. It is the space they cannot occupy. 

One day you will notice that there is more value, more passion, more humanity on the outside of the gilded cage. That's our space and they can't take that from us.

name: Andreas
tweet:
The only competitive difference we have is our principles. If you support open, public, borderless, neutral, censorship resistant and decentralized system, they cannot compete. 

They cannot offer liberty as a competitive differentiator. No regulator will allow it.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@rohangrey @gladstein But but... there's no financial institution behind a decentralized stablecoin. Who would you apply the regulation to?

name: Andreas
tweet: The most interesting thing about the STABLE Act is not whether it will be enacted (it won't). It's that it can only apply, by definition, to centralized fiat-backed stablecoins, therefore making decentralized alternatives even more attractive.

tweet:

name: Andreas
tweet: @Haitian_Dexter No. Moving the same asset (eg. Bitcoin) from one account to another account or wallet you own is not a taxable event. It might be misconstrued by the exchange as such and reported to the IRS (damn 1099-K!), but you can correct that in your own tax return.

name: Andreas
tweet:
The best way to avoid this nasty trap is to:

- Earn bitcoin and self-custody
or
- Buy bitcoin, withdraw and self-custody

But if you didn't start there, take a moment and some professional advice to think about next steps.

name: Andreas
tweet: @Sebaldian Yes, maybe, possibly, depends. Ask an accountant.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Every rule has exceptions. It's incredibly important to understand and practice the principles of financial sovereignty and independence. 

But... no rule should be followed to the point of compounding a small mistake with a much worse mistake.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Dare I say: DYOR 

...and also get a qualified and licensed accountant, financial advisor, or tax advisor.

name: Andreas
tweet: I am not an accountant and I cannot give tax advice. I am speaking only of my personal experience in a single jurisdiction. But those offering the "sell and move" advice are not accountants either and I think they're wrong, dangerously so.

name: Andreas
tweet: You should always be the one choosing the time of any taxable event and doing say in the most tax-advantageous way. Don't force a tax bill or worse have a tax bill force a sale and another tax bill.

name: Andreas
tweet:
As the author of the slogan "not your keys, not your coins", I feel I need to warn people to be pragmatic. Don't create a massive and unexpected tax bill for yourself for a point of principle. 

Let it sit for a year and learn the lesson. Buy/sell somewhere else in the mean time

name: Andreas
tweet: You could suddenly find yourself owing from 10 to 37% in the amount "gained" since you bought it. If you've already bought Bitcoin with the USD, you might have to sell it to pay the taxes.  Which would then trigger ANOTHER short-term capital gains taxable event.

name: Andreas
tweet: In the US and many other countries, this will trigger a so-called "taxable event", which will make you responsible for capital gains taxes. Worse, if you held for less than a year, you are subject to SHORT TERM capital gains taxes, which are taxed as ordinary income (!)

name: Andreas
tweet:
Others are jumping with this advice:

Sell it, get dollars, move the dollars to a "proper" exchange and buy Bitcoin you can withdraw. 

Here's why this might be terrible advice:

name: Andreas
tweet:
I'm seeing a lot of newbies who have bought Bitcoin in the last year on a NO-WITHDRAWAL service like Paypal or Robinhood. 

They learn about "not your keys, not your coins" and then they find out they can't withdraw. 

...

name: Andreas
tweet:
I'm about to give some rather unexpected advice:

Under some circumstances, it is best to leave Bitcoin on an exchange

name: Andreas
tweet:
Anyone can make a system cheap and fast. All they do is make it centralized and insecure. 

Of course, they won't tell you about that tradeoff. You won't even see it until someone tries to shut the system down or censor your transactions. 

You'll wish you paid a fee to be free

name: Andreas
tweet: If you're not choosing priority in a (necessarily) scarce system, then someone else is choosing priority for you. Perhaps they think your application is not important or it is spam. It's either fee markets or software despots. I choose fee markets.

name: Andreas
tweet:
If you want to have control over this vital part of the Bitcoin system, you need to carefully choose a wallet that allows you to control these things. A non-custodial wallet where you can set the fee rate, get good estimates and "bump" with RBF and CPFP. 

Choose well!

name: Andreas
tweet:
Transaction fees are a complicated topic, but they're part of what makes Bitcoin free and decentralized. No one but you can decide how "important" a transaction is. You decide and you tell the miners with your fee choice. 

/19

name: Andreas
tweet:
That also means that sometimes your transaction will get dropped from most places but re-broadcast by nodes that have kept it. That can delay the eventual confirmation/rejection of your Tx, leaving it in limbo longer. 

/18

name: Andreas
tweet:
The queue where transactions are held before confirmation is called "the mempool". Thing is however, there is no "the" mempool. There is "a mempool" on every Bitcoin node. It's a decentralized system. Every node keeps a mempool of waiting transactions. 

/17

name: Andreas
tweet:
That's because the reason the network isn't confirming it is that there are too many transactions queued competing for space. The queue itself is limited in size, so the same thing (congestion) preventing your Tx from confirming is likely to cause it to be dropped faster too.
/16

name: Andreas
tweet:
How long can a transaction stay "stuck". If the network remains congested and the fee remains low, it can be up to 14 days before the network drops it and you can see the balance again. "Up to" because it usually takes 2-3 days before the network drops your Tx.

/15

name: Andreas
tweet:
The transaction spending hasn't happened until... it has. Before confirmation, you have the money. After confirmation the recipient has the money. A block mined containing your Tx signals the change in state. 

/14

name: Andreas
tweet:
In order to prevent weird user behavior, your wallet will "hide" the balance of coins that you have tried to spend with a pending transaction. It will show your balance decreased by that amount. But in reality, the coins are still in your wallet.

/13

name: Andreas
tweet:
Bitcoin transactions are "atomic", meaning they are indivisible. The money is not removed from your wallet and sent somewhere before arriving at another wallet. If the transaction isn't confirmed, you have the money. If it is confirmed, the recipient has the money. No limbo

/12

name: Andreas
tweet:
First of all, DON'T PANIC. It's important to understand that in Bitcoin your money can't get lost "in limbo". If you create a transaction and it is not getting confirmed, your money is not at risk of being lost. It will either confirm or it won't and your money is safe

/11

name: Andreas
tweet:
Now, you're ready to send a transaction. If you have RBF, pick a low fee and see what happens. Later you can increase the fee and keep increasing it until you get the result you want. But what if you already sent a transaction, without RBF and it got stuck?

/10

name: Andreas
tweet:
Again, good wallets do Replace-By-Fee (RBF) and Child-Pays-For-Parent (CPFP) to help you manage a congested network and not get your Tx stuck. If your wallet doesn't do those things... consider changing wallets. 

/9

name: Andreas
tweet:
Before sending a transaction you should also check if your wallet supports fee "bumping" with RBF or CPFP. If you can later "bump" the fee up, you can afford to be cheap at first and see if you get lucky. If you can't bump, you run the risk of getting your Tx stuck. 

/8

name: Andreas
tweet:
If you use a wallet that creates "legacy" addresses that start with a "1", then choose a different wallet and move your money when the network isn't congested. 

Addresses that start with "3" (wrapped Segwit) are better. Those that start with "bc1" (native Segwit)  are best

/7

name: Andreas
tweet:
If your wallet doesn't allow you to estimate fees or its fee estimation seems to be too conservative, use a different wallet. Another big reason for high fees is legacy address use. Different bitcoin addresses cost up to 40% less in fees for the sender. 

/6

name: Andreas
tweet:
Some wallets won't let you set the fee rate or confirmation target. Some wallets also estimate fees very conservatively and aggressively overpay fees. That's because if your transaction is stuck you complain to the wallet devs. If you overpay fees you blame the bitcoin devs

/5

name: Andreas
tweet:
At a current fee rate, you might have to pay 0.0002 BTC or so to get your transaction confirmed within 3 blocks. That's for a typical sized transaction. 

/4

name: Andreas
tweet:
Transaction fees are measured in satoshis per virtual byte (vbyte). Different transaction types have different sizes, depending on the complexity, number of inputs/outputs and address type being spent. 

A typical size (one input, two outputs) is about 144 vB. 

/3

name: Andreas
tweet:
First, check and see how congested things are. A great site for this is Johoe's Bitcoin Mempool statistics:

https://t.co/geFf63lldz

That rising mountain is 6hrs of activity. There are already 30,000 transactions willing to pay more than 50 satoshis per byte

2/ https://t.co/GTaam5fQKg

name: Andreas
tweet:
During times of extreme market excitement, the capacity of Bitcoin gets strained. That means that Bitcoin transactions become expensive and slow. Some may even become "stuck". Here's what to do...

name: Andreas
tweet:
@fatihdeolecek @slush The keys are backed up in a mnemonic. It's the mnemonic you need to audit:

- Is the mnemonic still there?
- Is the tamper evident container (bag) still untouched
- Is the mnemonic legible?

If yes, you can replace a broken HW. Don't need to fret.

name: Andreas

- KeepKey
- Ledger
- Trezor

If unsure: pick whichever ships sooner, directly from the vendor

name: Andreas
tweet:
Electrum + Tails is a terrible idea.
Bitaddress + Tails is a terrible idea.
Ian Coleman's BIP39 generator + old laptop is a terrible idea. 

BUY A HARDWARE WALLET. Follow the instructions, keep it simple. Stop trying to improvise or follow someone's harebrained DIY recipe

name: Andreas
tweet: DIY security is incredibly risky. Very few people have the technical skills to pull it off. Few people can tell when they've surpassed their skill level and made a mistake.

name: Andreas
tweet:

DON'T DO IT. 

Buy a hardware wallet, keep it simple.

tweet: @hodldogofficial In summary there are many lawful activities that might be enabled by a tool that does the same thing that every browser does when you watch a video. This is a terrible precedent and Github is shamefully gutless in its actions

name: Andreas
tweet:
@hodldogofficial I also backup before I upload, but I didn't have older videos made before I started making archive copies of everything. Also livestreams. Also captions (which Youtube-dl handles brilliantly).

My videos are also CC-BY licensed, so others have the right to do this too.

name: Andreas
tweet: @matiwinnetou Ultimately this serves as a chilling effect for software developers. DMCA is being abused (again).

name: Andreas
tweet:
@matiwinnetou Yes, there are mirrors. I'm not having any difficulty bypassing Github's stupid takedown. 

The problem is that collaborative software development is damaged by this type of policy. I can download the software but I can't collaborate in its development as easily.

name: Andreas
tweet:
There are lot of tools missing for YT creators. We have to cobble together a bunch of things to manage our channels and make them useful to our audience. This in turn makes them useful and insanely profitable to YT.

That includes backup. 

tl;dr; Fuck you RIAA, once again.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Why does this matter? For the same reason that VHS wasn't banned, even though the same monopolists tried: Substantial Non-Infringing Use. 

The courts in the US found that as long as there was non-infringing (ie lawful) use for this technology then there is no basis to ban it.

name: Andreas
tweet:
In case people were wondering about why RIAA and Github are wrong about taking down youtube-dl:

As a YT creator, I use youtube-dl to make a backup of my channel - my own content. A feature YT doesn't offer and which I absolutely need because no one should trust any platform 100%

name: Andreas
tweet: @TowerOBable @Adelgary @piramida @ntnchez @lopp No, that's not how forks work, sorry.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@TowerOBable @Adelgary @piramida @ntnchez @lopp I recommend a video talk I did on this topic called "Forkology" that better explains the difference between soft and hard forks. 

Nodes that are not upgraded would reject these new transactions and reject the blocks they are inside, leading to the un-upgraded nodes hard forking

name: Andreas
tweet:
@Adelgary @TowerOBable @piramida @ntnchez @lopp Agreed, I don't think it is trivial. It would require significant coordination and most likely a hard-fork (even more coordination). It's doable, but not easy. 

Easier in L2, where for example LN uses milli-satoshis. Still rounded up on channel closure, but useful for payments

name: Andreas
tweet: @TowerOBable @Adelgary @piramida @ntnchez @lopp There may be a way to do this that is backwards-compatible with non-upgraded nodes (soft), but I don't see it. Then again, many were surprised with Luke-Jr's invention of a way to soft-fork Segwit and avoid a hard fork. Who know what someone might come up with?

name: Andreas
tweet: @TowerOBable @Adelgary @piramida @ntnchez @lopp Not exactly. A soft fork allows existing (unapgraded) nodes to continue following the chain: it is a narrowing of the rules. This is likely a hard fork because it would be an expansion of the validation rules to allow a bigger vout value field or new Tx version number

name: Andreas
tweet: The worst part of this rebound scam is that even when I tell people several times that their money is gone and they're being scammed again, they don't want to believe. They don't want their last hope to die. They would rather believe a comforting lie, and they get scammed again

name: Andreas
tweet: The only thing you can recover from stolen cryptocurrency is the lesson: don't give your keys or your money. Don't provide "access codes" or type mnemonics into websites. Don't let others "set up" accounts for you.

name: Andreas
tweet:
Scammers who try this sc will keep making excuses and keep asking for more new fees. They string their victims along by keeping the hope of recovery alive. 

This scam uses the sunk cost fallacy to re-victimise again and again.

name: Andreas
tweet:
If you have had cryptocurrency stolen because of a scam, there is no way to recover it. 

Any request for a recovery fee is a classic "advance fee" scam, similar to the "Nigerian prince" type of scam. Send $10 to get $100 etc.

name: Andreas
tweet:
I've heard this half a dozen times in the last month. 

I'm guessing this is often the same scammer coming back for a second bite of a victim who has proved to be easy to scam. Or maybe a new scammer looking for this specific profile of victim.

name: Andreas
tweet:
I'm hearing frequently about a type of "rebound scam"

People who have been scammed out of crypto are told there is a way to recover some of the funds, if they send a "recovery fee". They get scammed twice (rebound) because of desperation and false hope.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet: @swaaalla @lukechilds The 512 bits are literally split in half. The "left" 256 (most-significant) bits go to make the private key the right 256 bits go to make the chaincode.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@swaaalla @lukechilds Yes. 

I realize now that this picture:

https://t.co/QMz4f7mT4D 

is wrong. https://t.co/wLVXs4B98B

name: Andreas
tweet: @swaaalla @lukechilds https://t.co/sm7XpVyaki https://t.co/U6WS6zgTKP

name: Andreas
tweet:
@swaaalla @lukechilds The entire string, with spaces, is put into PBKDF2. 

If there is an optional passphrase, it is appended to the string. If no passphrase, then the actual word "mnemonic" is appended to the string. Then the whole resulting string is hashed by PBKDF2 2048 times.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@swaaalla @lukechilds The last step does not produce a "BIP39 seed". The BIP39 mnemonic is input to PBKDF2

The last step produces 512 bits (seed) which get split into a master private key and a Master chaincode. 

An xpriv encodes both (key+chaincode) into Base58 encoding

https://t.co/WFb2BGgeaj

name: Andreas
tweet:
@swaaalla @lukechilds There's a mistake in an earlier stage

BIP32 does not take the binary seed and put it into PBKDF2. It takes the actual ASCII words and puts them into PBKDF2. That's why a Japanese mnemonic and an English mnemonic are not interchangeable even if same entropy

tweet: Pull the plank out of your eye before you point at the mote in mine. Less gotcha, more building, more thinking, more learning, more nuance.

tweet:

tweet:

name: Andreas
tweet:
The nuance is what was missed by all the gloating investment "experts" who have been jumping up and down for several days, thinking they found a gotcha that invalidates Ethereum. Demonstrating their lack of understanding of the technology and its economics. 

/17

name: Andreas
tweet:
On top of all that you have to scan the blockchain to create a correct current state, based on the mining rewards. All of which means that there is NUANCE to this question. 

/16

name: Andreas
tweet:
Therefore, your methoology for calculating ETH supply will determine your answer. The exact timing (reference point) of your question will determine your answer and it will change every 15-30 seconds. Whether you count burned ETH will determine your answer. 

/15

name: Andreas
tweet:
But just like Bitcoin's mempool, not all nodes see all uncles at the same time, meaning that if you are asking for a real-time snapshot, you will get different answers. That's not because there isn't consensus, it's because consensus on uncles is a few blocks behind the tip. 
/14

name: Andreas
tweet:
The consensus mechanism can count the *exact* issuance of ETH, as long as you set a specific block height that has had all it's uncles counted and use that as a point of reference. 

/13

name: Andreas
tweet:
It's important to understand that uncles arrive with a slight delay from the parent block and are incorporated on an "eventual" basis up to 6 blocks after the parent. This means the issuance at any height isn't finalized until a few blocks later, when all uncles are counted. 
/12

name: Andreas
tweet:
Ok I lied, it's 3 purposes - 
(3) The rewarding of uncles reduces the incentive of mining empty blocks, since the race is not winner-takes all. 

/11

name: Andreas
tweet:
(2) It acts as a sort of on-chain mining pool mechanism, since it doesn't penalize second-finish miners with a zero reward. This makes lower-hashrate miners able to compete as solo miners without losing potential reward

/10

name: Andreas
tweet:
This mechanism serves two purposes: 

(1) it allows much faster block times (40x of bitcoin), without creating a whole mess of stale blocks that get no reward. Ethereum doesn't discard stales, it rewards them

/9

name: Andreas
tweet:
This is a critical point to understand: ETH supply issued as rewards doesn't go 100% to the winning block each confirmation. In Ethereum, up to 87% of the block reward goes to uncles, and some is further distributed to nephews (children of uncles). Part also goes to the parent
/8

name: Andreas
tweet:
Then there are "uncles". In Bitcoin, PoW is a winner-takes-all mechanism. Not in Ethereum, which uses a Greedy Heaviest Observed Tree (GHOST) protocol to include stale blocks with a lower reward. These are caller "uncles" or "ommers"

/7

name: Andreas
tweet:
Bitcoin does 1 block every 10 minutes. Ethereum does ~40 in that time. So exactly when you ask the question, will determine what answer you get. It won't be a stable answer for 10 minutes, it will change every 15-30 seconds or so. 

/6

name: Andreas
tweet:
You can easily see how this plays out in Bitcoin too, if you've paid any attention to all the errors in popular blockchain explorers over the years. Take a Bitcoin metric like "current hashrate" and you will find a dozen different answers depending on where you look

/3

name: Andreas
tweet:
First of all a block explorer is a very limited view of any blockchain. These are user-interface tools that abstract important details and translate them for the user's benefit. They each have a point-of-view that is the result of their data collection and analysis methodology
/2

name: Andreas
tweet:
There's a reason they used Segwit. These addresses are likely to get a lot of smaller amounts. Aggregating all that UTXO will cost fees, but a lot less in fees with native Segwit addresses. Worth the reduced target zone (fewer victim wallets will work) to save fees. 

Segwit FTW!

name: Andreas
tweet: I told you "mainstream" was a double-edged sword

name: Andreas
tweet:
This was Twitter getting hacked. The fact that scammers asked for a good, liquid and easily used form of digital money is not a slight on bitcoin, it's a compliment. 

If a kidnapper asks for uncut diamonds and swiss bearer bonds do you blame the diamonds and the bonds?

name: Andreas
tweet: In case anyone filed to notice, the Twitter hackers are using native Segwit addresses and BTC. Just sayin'

name: Andreas
tweet: Given the accounts that got hacked more recently (Apple, Uber, Gates, Musk, etc), I am now leaning towards this being an internal compromise of a Twitter system, not an API attack from a social aggregator service.

name: Andreas
tweet: This is one possible explanation and probably the scariest, because it means there's nothing that can be done by users to prevent this.

name: Andreas
tweet: For an ulimited time, if you send me money I will make excellent free and open-licensed content available to everyone.

tweet: @il_trep Don't know. This is pure speculation (good reasoning but not enough data). It could be any of dozens of such services, browser extensions or apps.

Why do they rob banks, because that's where the money is. Why do they hack crypto companies.. same.

tweet: Password changed. It was >25 character random full-character-set, but there's no harm in changing it. Also, don't use SMS 2FA (I don't, ever, anywhere). Use TOTP 2FA, at minimum, or a hardware security key, at best.

Criminals have private and untraceable money. The only question is will you and I also have it?

tweet:

name: Andreas
tweet:

AML? Bullshit

Don't lie.

name: Andreas
tweet: @SindreamTim Line up and take a number please. The Bitcoin Obituary section is currently experiencing long wait times. Your obituary submission is important to us, so please stay on the line. A representative will be with you in no less than 10 years. You are currently 4,521st in line.

name: Andreas
tweet: @mezie16 @lightning @openoms @rootzoll @fefolamas @LNnodeLightMeUp @lightninginabox @RTL_App @lightning_hood @LNJunkies You do, eventually. You balance is stuck because you were unable to cooperatively close and instead the close happened with a commitment transaction that imposes a timelock.

name: Andreas
tweet: @Arcadia845 Many pools were building candidate blocks, perhaps with message or without. Of those only f2pool was seen because it was the first to find a valid solution to the Proof-of-Work algorithm.

name: Andreas
tweet: @Arcadia845 At the time that 629,999 was mined, f2pool was ready and had customized their mining software to put this message into the candidate block. They were lucky enough to be able to find Proof-of-Work before anyone else and make it a valid block. We would have never seen it otherwise

name: Andreas
tweet: @Arcadia845 The mining equipment tries to find a specific number that when plugged in to the candidate block header produces a block hash that is valid. It takes billions of guesses. If they succeed they tell everyone and their candidate block becomes *the* block that is accepted.

name: Andreas
tweet: @Arcadia845 Every miner constructs a "candidate block" on their computer. They insert a coinbase transaction that they construct, with a payout to them (reward + fees) & can include any message they want. They add all the transactions they can fit. Then they send it to their mining equipment

name: Andreas
tweet:
All the action happens in line 1247

nSubsidy >>= halvings;

The ">>=" is the bitwise-right-shift operator that shifts the nSubsidy integer to the right. It is shifted by as many bits as the value of halvings (3 bits this time). 

Each bit right shift divides it by half

name: Andreas
tweet:
The C++ code (in Bitcoin Core client) that will make the "bitcoin halving" happen 

Constant values:
nSubsidyHalvingInterval = 210,000
nHeight (at the time) = 630,000
COIN = 100,000,000 (satoshi)

Find it in https://t.co/O9oq8CgJg1 https://t.co/DW6V24RKqa

tweet:

Instagram and FB are bad too

tweet: @JoelRayguns Then you know that on the Internet you can run multiple different routing protocols as you want, all of which can be used to route IP. LN started with 'source routing' just like the Internet and can support a plethora of different routing protocols simultaneously

name: Andreas
tweet: @JoelRayguns LN has multiple routing protocols and more can be added. This is not a real concern.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@JoelRayguns I value implemented software over white papers. 

LN already has this implemented. It's called Atomic Multi Path (AMP)

name: Andreas
tweet: @JoelRayguns LN already has multipath routing (AMP) as described in this paper. Routing in LN can be done by a variety of protocols, it is not tied to just one. Different parts of the network can use different protocols

name: Andreas
tweet: @nano_private Consensus includes validating nodes which in Bitcoin is all of the nodes. This prevents a coup d'etat by miners (as proven in 2017) and therefore forces miners to follow consensus or face risk of great losses

name: Andreas
tweet: @nano_private Nodes play an important role. They can (partially) override miners by not propagating transactions or blocks that violate consensus. Also if they are economically active/important nodes they control which transactions/blocks/forks are valuable by enforcing consensus.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@abcdehoop Timestamps are constrained to be past the average of the last 11 blocks and no more than 2 hrs in the future of each validating nodes clock. 

A block can have an earlier timestamp than its parent. Since it contains the parent hash we know it was mined after the parent.

tweet: @bitcoin_works They're not panic selling. They have specific risk metrics that force a stop loss sale at specific standard-deviation movements. They are auto selling without emotion. Same thing that is happening at NYSE and NASDAQ for equties

name: Andreas
tweet: @bitcoin_works Nothing has changed, but people are trying to provide ex post facto rationalization on market moves and relate them to the fundamentals. This was not related to fundamentals. Every asset dropped worldwide, the riskier ones dropped harder.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@one_block_more Nothing to do with that. If 50% of miners drop out, the rest become much more profitable and stable. Yes some centralization, but no impact on security, as we were at 50% less hash rate 18 months ago. 

This was all "market sentiment", not a single asset was spared worldwide

name: Andreas
tweet:
@bitcoin_works Nobody said they shouldn't trade or be welcomed. We need investors and speculators for liquidity and broader use. I don't believe in purity tests or ideological "hodl" bollocks. 

I'm simply explaining why "mainstream" investors change the behavior of this thing.

name: Andreas
tweet:
@nilspn Agreed. We need investors, speculators and "mainstream". It's just that those investors bring with them increased volatility and correlation (emotional) to other markets. 

It's important to understand why these things are happening so as not to act on (other people's) fear.

name: Andreas
tweet:
You wanted "institutional investors" and "mainstream adoption"?

This is what it looks like: Absent the principles of decentralization, traded as a high-volatility asset to add "spice" to a portfolio.

As soon as price gets uncomfortable, they drop it like a hot potato. We don't.

name: Andreas

name: Andreas
tweet: @kaktaka123 @stevefloyds @BrendanBlumer @toju_kaka @eosfly2thesky2 @marketcapone @jakedienelt Because the rules are checked by all nodes on the network & invalid blocks are not propagated. Economically important nodes (exchanges, merchants, large wallets) act as checks-and-balances. Miners who change the rules fork into a new coin (eg BCH), they don't change the original

name: Andreas
tweet: @AdelElmessiry @stevefloyds @BrendanBlumer @toju_kaka @eosfly2thesky2 @marketcapone @jakedienelt You cannot take other people's money with a 51% attack. Can only double spend. No exchange will allow you to withdraw before 6 confirmations. So it's a very very risky game to play, which is why no one has successfully executed against strong PoW coins like Bitcoin

name: Andreas
tweet: @kaktaka123 @stevefloyds @BrendanBlumer @toju_kaka @eosfly2thesky2 @marketcapone @jakedienelt You can't dictate the future, because the rules are not just enforced by miners but also by economically active nodes. Miners can't unilaterally change the rules.

name: Andreas
tweet: @stevefloyds @BrendanBlumer @toju_kaka @eosfly2thesky2 @marketcapone @jakedienelt Note that the site you linked shows the 1hr cost of a 51% attack at almost $1 million. To erase just 300 blocks would cost almost $50 million and that's just 2 days of blocks. Erasing a month? Ridiculously expensive = immutable in practice

name: Andreas
tweet: @stevefloyds @BrendanBlumer @toju_kaka @eosfly2thesky2 @marketcapone @jakedienelt I disagree. 51% attacks are only shallow attacks against immutability, can affect a few "surface" blocks for a double spend. Beyond a few blocks, a strong PoW chain is  immutable. A 51% attack would have to be sustained for months to rewrite deep history, at massive cost

name: Andreas
tweet: @BlakeRizzo24 Sorry for the reaction (deleted since)

name: Andreas
tweet: @BlakeRizzo24 You responded to my statement about my actions and my moral position, not a generic statement about expert witnesses.

name: Andreas
tweet: @whalepool I don't care what you believe. My reputation for neutrality and objectivity is well established. No one, no matter what they pay for my time, gets to buy my opinion. I will, and always have, speak the truth as I see it. That's what makes me a good witness.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet: @bennd77 Because a couple of articles are already stirring up discussion and people misunderstand the role of an expert witness and the motivation behind my engagement. I want to clarify and clear misunderstandings

name: Andreas
tweet: @RydesaurusRex Thanks

name: Andreas
tweet:
I won't comment any further on either case, as that would be improper.

I only confirm that I am engaged as an expert witness, on the plaintiff's sides, in two currently litigated cases. 

I have explained my motivation. Agree or not, that's why I do it. 

That's all.

name: Andreas
tweet:
I'm good at explaining this stuff and I've had lots of practice. As such, I think I can do a good job, even under stressful conditions. 

I'm not interested in taking sides and I don't enjoy the drama. I do this despite the drama, because I think it is a way to serve justice.

name: Andreas
tweet:
That's what an expert witness does - they don't take sides. 

I think it is VERY important to have judges and juries understand this technology and have unbiased and accurate information about bitcoin and open blockchains. 

Justice is served by having educated juries and judges

name: Andreas
tweet: I am an expert witness in two current cases. As an expert witness, I am a neutral "explainer" of how bitcoin works, for the judge or jury. I am not taking a position on the facts of either case, nor do I have knowledge of the facts. I have been careful NOT to develop an opinion.

name: Andreas
Andreas
tweet: @csahoo @whalepool I am an expert witness in the case, not a fact witness. My role is to explain bitcoin to the jury and judge. I have no knowledge or position in the facts of the case, neutrality is the whole point of being an expert witness.
